<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_NetworkGetHostName:
```c
int32 OS_NetworkGetHostName(char *host_name, size_t name_len)
{
    int32 return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(host_name);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(name_len);

    /* delegate to low-level API */
    return_code = OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(host_name, name_len);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* return an empty string on failure, just in case */
        host_name[0] = 0;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_NetworkGetHostName:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_SIZE(val) ARGCHECK((val)>0&&(val)<(UINT32_MAX/2),OS_ERR_INVALID_SIZE)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#define OS_CHECK_SIZE(val) ARGCHECK((val)>0&&(val)<(UINT32_MAX/2),OS_ERR_INVALID_SIZE)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: OS_CHECK_SIZE only validates that the size is > 0 and less than UINT32_MAX/2 and does not call any <string.h> functions. In the shown usage (OS_NetworkGetHostName), this check (together with OS_CHECK_POINTER) guarantees name_len>0 and host_name != NULL, so writing host_name[0] = 0 on error does not access beyond the buffer. Therefore Rule 21.17 is not violated.
